comm with blue x that's right as

be commonly referred to as blue tongs
you know I should probably trademark

and I told you I was going to show you
how to make them and that's what I'm
about to do so for our first step here
of course we're gonna have to cut up
some bread and unlike most standard
crouton recipes were actually going to
use fresh bread I really think using the
fresh bread for this gives you a crouton
that's slightly less hard even though
the final products going to come out
Chris no matter what you use but
sometimes are really hard crispy instead
of sort of crumbly crispy does that make
any sense at all
I will try to explain that further on
the blog post so I'm going to do about
half a loaf here and I'm going to cut
that into about half inch thick slices
and then we'll just cut those slices
down this way and then of course into
cubes and I really think somewhere
between a half inch and one inch is the
perfect crouton size once you get bigger
than that you're risking some serious a
roof of the mouth abrasions beside you
go to stick a giant crouton with a fork
and a lot of times as shatters and flies
off your plates which is embarrassing so
I'm not a big fan of the giant crouton
and by the way I really had to edit
that's pretty tight because I forgot to
lock the wheels on my table I found this
shaking to be distracting and annoying
so let's fast forward to when these are
all cuts and what we'll do is we'll toss
those in a bowl and we will start the
blue cheese in process and to begin that
we're going to spoon over copious
amounts of hot melted butter I just did
mine in the microwave and I know olive
oil is a much more common fat to use
when you're making croutons
but with these blue tones I really think
the butter carries the blue cheese
flavor much more effectively so we're
gonna dump in a bunch of butter and then
I'm going to start grating in some blue
cheese and you're probably thinking how
can you gradient blue cheese it's way
too sticky well not if the cheese is
frozen it's not so before you start this
make sure you throw your blue cheese in
the freezer until it firms up and that
way you should be able to create nice
small pieces like this and what we'll do
is we'll grate some in and we'll give
that a toss and those pieces of blue
cheese are going to quickly soften and
mix with the butter and hopefully get
smeared all over those bread cubes so
I'm going to give it a mix and I'm going
to give it another grain of blue cheese
of course how much you put on is up to
you but if you can try to put on the
perfect amount so great on some more
we'll mix that up
of course if your cube seem like they
need a little more butter put some in
mine didn't look that way but I added a
little anyway and I'm gonna give it
another grading to blue cheese and I'll
mix that in and by the way the only
reason I'm using a spoon here is because
I didn't want to get blue cheese on my
camera but you know what for this type
of operation your hands are so much
better so I switched and I finished that
off with my bare hands and then once we
think our bread cubes are sufficiently
smeared with butter and blue cheese
we'll go ahead and transfer those onto a
lined baking sheet and spread them out a
little bit at that point is pretty much
ready for the oven
except I decided to do one more gradient
over the top because I figured if there
was going to be a problem with these
croutons it wouldn't be from too much
bleu cheese it would be from not enough
so I graded out a little extra and at
that point we're going to place it in
the center of a 350 degree oven for
about 15-20 minutes at which point it
should look like this and just be
starting to get golden and what we'll do
is we'll take a spatula and give that a
good mix before we grate over a little
more bleu cheese which by the way was
returned to the freezer so it stays nice
and firm so like I said give those a
toss and then we'll grate over a little
more bleu cheese and place those back in
the oven until they are beautifully
browned and crunchy and sure if you want
you can pull those out give another toss
add a little more cheese that's up to
you you are the Louis Vuitton of your
blue cheese crouton so it's up to you to
discover how much is too much having
said that you probably can't put too
much on these but I know a few you will
try but anyway believe it or not I
didn't add any more bleu cheese I just
cooked oats for another 15 or 20 minutes
until they were beautifully browned and

it looks just like a regular crouton
pretty much but when you bite in it has

anyway that's it blue cheese croutons or
